The TARDBP gene encodes the TAR DNA-binding protein 43 (TDP-43), which plays a critical role in RNA processing and DNA repair. Mutations in TARDBP are strongly associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a neurodegenerative disease characterized by the progressive loss of motor neurons. These mutations can lead to the mislocalization and aggregation of TDP-43 in the cytoplasm, disrupting its normal function and contributing to neuronal dysfunction and death. TARDBP is also implicated in frontotemporal dementia (FTD), particularly in cases where TDP-43 pathology is present. The pathway described includes mitochondrial complex I components, highlighting the interplay between nuclear and mitochondrial gene dysfunction in neurodegeneration. 

\boxed{Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)}

The VHL allele is part of a pathway involving the VHL-E3 ubiquitin ligase complex (VHL, RBX1, ELOC, ELOB, CUL2), which regulates HIF1A under normoxia. Under hypoxia, HIF1A accumulates and interacts with ARNT to activate transcription of downstream genes (SLC2A1, VEGFA, TGFB, PDGFB, TGFA), promoting angiogenesis, cell survival, and proliferation. The pathway's activation under normal oxygen conditions due to VHL mutations contributes to tumorigenesis.

\boxed{von Hippel-Lindau disease}

The APP allele, through its role in the amyloidogenic pathway, contributes to the accumulation of beta-amyloid (Abeta) peptides. This leads to the activation of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (mAChR), triggering downstream signaling involving GNAQ, PLCB, IP3, and ITPR, which increases intracellular calcium. The APRT gene encodes adenine phosphoribosyltransferase, an enzyme involved in the salvage pathway of purine nucleotide synthesis. Mutations in APRT can lead to a deficiency in this enzyme, impairing the body's ability to recycle adenine into ATP. This results in the accumulation of 2,8-dihydroxyadenine, which forms crystals and deposits in the urinary tract, kidneys, and other organs. The condition is known as **2,8-dihydroxyadenine urolithiasis** or **adenine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency**. TPO catalyzes iodination of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin (TG), forming monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), which are precursors to triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4).
